<snip>
> I somehow believe that is better, if these two concerns are separa=
ble
> and one could mix them as needed, because not every client needs the
=
> knowledge of the underlying resource/model description.
</snip>

From my =
POV, a key diff between RDF message designs and hypermedia
message designs =
is that RDF design focuses on domain-level semantics
and hypermedia design =
focuses on protocol-level semantics,

Without too much trouble, I have been=
 able to design hypermedia types
that _also_ express domain semantics (i.e.=
 domain-specific elements,
attributes, etc.) that a wide range of clients c=
an consume (even those
who are not "interested in" the domain semantics ava=
ilable in the
hypermedia type).

However, I've not yet been able to design =
an RDF media type that
_also_ expresses protocol-level semantics (i.e. navi=
gate|embed,
protocol method, body|uri variables, idempotency, etc.) that a =
wide
range of clients can consume (even those not "interested in" the
proto=
col semantics available in the RDF media type).

RDFa seems to come the clo=
sest to mixing both design goals and it
starts from the hypermedia design t=
hen adds RDF elements.  I haven't
found an inverse of the RDFa model.

mca
=
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/foaf.=
rdf#me




On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 12:30, Bob Ferris <zazi@...> wrote:
=
> Hi Markus,
>
> well, from my POV (a Semantic Web biased one), I would agr=
ee. However, I
> always got and get the impression that the REST/hypermedia=
 community
> doesn't agree on this equation*.
> I guess, it has something t=
o do with the hypermedia support that
> surrounds the utilisation of link r=
elation types, i.e. they are values
> of rel attributes of tags, e.g., "lin=
k", "a", or "area". These tags and
> their attributes define the processing=
 (e.g. enc-type, method, ...) of
> referred resources (in the media type de=
finition). Furthermore, in such
> a hypermedia context a client should know=
 whether it is a navigational
> link, an embedded link, etc.
> On the other=
 side, RDF is a data model or knowledge representation
> structure, which s=
hould be embeddable into other existing hypermedia
> media types (as it alr=
eady can done with RDFa, see XHTML+RDFa). So RDF
> serialisation (/represen=
tation) formats doesn't need this
> functionalities themselves.
> I somehow=
 believe that is better, if these two concerns are separable
> and one coul=
d mix them as needed, because not every client needs the
> knowledge of the=
 underlying resource/model description.
>
> Cheers,
>
>
> Bo
>
>
> *) which=
 is so obvious from my POV :) (because it's all about binary
> relations in=
 that context)
>
> PS: Interesting to read in that context:
> http://www.am=
undsen.com/blog/archives/1065 +
> http://www.amundsen.com/blog/archives/108=
3
>
> PPS: I still believe that H-Factor is a very good measurement for
> h=
ypermedia, see http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/hfactor/
>
>

>> does nothing else than co=
nnecting two (data) nodes. If I know the
>> relationship of node B to node =
A I also know how to process it or if I would
>> be interested in following=
 that link.
>>
>> --
>> Markus Lanthaler

>> =A0> these relations=
, i.e., how to handle the referred object.
>> =A0> To sum up, link relation=

>> =A0> (RDF) property definiti=
ons. See also, e.g., [1] for a detailed

d related ones.
